neighborhood_overview: Bridgeport used to be called "Hardscrabble." Back in the day it was a hard-working, rough-and-tumble neighborhood famous for the stockyards and the Daley clan. Today Bridgeport stays true to its humble roots, notably lacking million dollar condos and ritzy boutiques, but its proximity to downtown (you can see the skyline) attracts people from near and far. Bridgeport has become one of the most ethnically diverse and vibrant neighborhoods in the city. Famous deep-dish pizzerias share the 'hood with taco joints, specialty Northern Chinese restaurants, and great coffee shops.

neighborhood_overview: Bridgeport used to be called "Hardscrabble." Back in the day it was a hard-working, rough-and-tumble neighborhood famous for the stockyards and the Daley clan. Today Bridgeport stays true to its humble roots, notably lacking million dollar condos and ritzy boutiques, but its proximity to downtown (you can see the skyline) attracts people from near and far. Bridgeport has become one of the most ethnically diverse and vibrant neighborhoods in the city. Famous deep-dish pizzerias share the 'hood with taco joints, specialty Northern Chinese restaurants, and great coffee shops.

You can pronounce my name the English way, the French way, or just call me Gv. I host this space with my husband John. We live in the apartment on the second floor of the building. We're both lifetime Chicago residents and have lived across the city, in Rogers Park, Pilsen, Roscoe Village, Logan Square, Wicker Park, and Humboldt Park. A few years ago we settled in Bridgeport. We took care to include details that matter to us when we travel, such as a coffee machine, a private outdoor space, and cotton bedding as opposed to polyester.

We have a small garden out back, which you're more than welcome to. If you see us out there messing with the flowers or playing with our (small, friendly, allergy-compatible) dog, please feel free to come chat with us! Bridgeport served as a shortcut for French traders who soon saw the economic potential for a canal. When Fort Dearborn was completed, what is now Bridgeport became Leigh's Place. Centered on James Leigh's farm, it became Chicago's first neighborhood. In 1836, the area was renamed Bridgeport. Historically, much of the neighborhood began as an Irish-American enclave. In the 1830s, large numbers of immigrants from Ireland started settling in this working-class neighborhood. neighborhood_overview: On Chicago’s South Side, quintessentially blue-collar Bridgeport is the city’s prime spot for taking in the art scene, finding amazing food, or catching a White Sox game. The enclave ranks among the city’s most diverse, with a Buddhist temple alongside a Benedictine monastery, and Mandarin, Spanish and Korean often overheard. Turn-of-the-century buildings are now galleries and art studios, a quarry is now a striking park [Palmisano], and a geometric boathouse by the notable architect Jeanne Gang is a great spot for rowing or practicing yoga along the Chicago River. Bridgeport is known for having a huge variety of hidden food gems and gin joints! Maria’s Packaged Goods & Community Bar (960 W 31st St) is part liquor store, part neighborhood tavern, and a chill and welcoming hipster hangout. Attached is Kimski, a Polish-Korean hybrid sausage stand. Nearby, Nana (Phone number hidden by Airbnb) S Halsted St) has become one of the most notable farm-to-table organic restaurants in Chicago. notes: Bridgeport is known for having a large number of police [and their families] living here and police headquarters three blocks away - so there are always police cars on the main streets. Always be careful in Chicago (especially late at night and/or when appearing lost, drunk, nervous, or confused) but know that, in general, Bridgeport is fairly safe.
transit: Bridgeport is on the near South Side, close to cultural enclaves like Pilsen and Chinatown to the north and Bronzeville to the east. Union Station [trains/busses] and Midway airport are closest transportation hubs.  Located on the corner of 35th and Halsted, a Divvy bike share station, Halsted Bus #8, and 35th Street bus are all right in front of the building. Red, Green, and Orange line Elevated Train stops are a short bus, fast bike, or long/ish walk away [easy in fine weather]. The apartment is a half hour by public transit [or bike] to Loop attractions and 25 minutes to South Loop to find movie theaters, Whole Foods, Target, DSW, Best Buy and almost anything you can think of. Fashionable neighborhoods of West Town, Wicker Park, and Logan Square are 50 min by public transit, 35 minute bike, 25 minute car. There is FREE year-round overnight street parking only one block away!
